natural problem: The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee?
natural solution: Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.

Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.

The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.

Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.

Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes committee_size :: nat and votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and candidates :: nat
assumes h0 : "candidates = 27"
and h1 : "\<forall>i < candidates. votes i \<le> committee_size"
and h2 : "\<forall>i < candidates. (votes i) * 100 / committee_size < votes i"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134
 ### Proof
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
 We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.
 Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.
 The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.
 $\centerline{{\bf OR}}$
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes committee_size :: nat and votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and candidates :: nat
assumes h0 : "candidates = 27"
and h1 : "\<forall>i < candidates. votes i \<le> committee_size"
and h2 : "\<forall>i < candidates. (votes i) * 100 / committee_size < votes i"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 27 candidates running for positions in a committee. Each candidate receives a certain number of votes which is less than or equal to the size of the committee. If each candidate receives less than one percent of the total committee size in votes, what is the minimum size that the committee could be? The final answer is 134.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes committee_size votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum votes {1..27} = committee_size"
and h1 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..27}. votes i * 100 / committee_size < votes i - 1"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes committee_size votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum votes {1..27} = committee_size"
and h1 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..27}. votes i * 100 / committee_size < votes i - 1"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a committee of 27 people, the total number of votes given to each person equals the size of the committee. However, for each person, the number of votes they receive is less than 1% of the committee size. What is the minimum size of the committee? The final answer is 134.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes votes :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and committee_size :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall>c. c \<in> {1..27} \<longrightarrow> votes c \<le> (committee_size * votes c) div 100 - 1"
and h1 : "committee_size = (\<Sum>c \<in> {1..27}. votes c)"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.

theorem
fixes votes :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and committee_size :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall>c. c \<in> {1..27} \<longrightarrow> votes c \<le> (committee_size * votes c) div 100 - 1"
and h1 : "committee_size = (\<Sum>c \<in> {1..27}. votes c)"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose we have a committee where each of the 27 members has a certain number of votes. The votes each member has is less than or equal to one less than their proportion of the total votes. If the size of the committee is equal to the total number of votes, what is the minimum possible size of the committee? The final answer is 134.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and total_votes :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_votes = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..27}. votes i)"
and h1 : "\<forall>i\<in>{1..27}. votes i > 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>i\<in>{1..27}. real (votes i) / real total_votes < real (votes i) / 100"
shows  "total_votes = 134"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134

 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.

 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and total_votes :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_votes = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..27}. votes i)"
and h1 : "\<forall>i\<in>{1..27}. votes i > 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>i\<in>{1..27}. real (votes i) / real total_votes < real (votes i) / 100"
shows  "total_votes = 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In an election, there are 27 candidates each receiving more than 0 votes. The total number of votes is the sum of the votes each candidate received. If the ratio of votes each candidate received to the total votes is less than the ratio of votes each candidate received to 100, what is the total number of votes? The final Answer is 134.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and total_votes :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_votes = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..27}. votes i)"
and h1 : "\<forall>i\<in>{1..27}. real (votes i) / real total_votes < real (votes i) / 100"
shows  "total_votes \<ge> 134"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134

 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.

Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.

 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and total_votes :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_votes = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..27}. votes i)"
and h1 : "\<forall>i\<in>{1..27}. real (votes i) / real total_votes < real (votes i) / 100"
shows  "total_votes \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Assume there are 27 candidates in an election, each receiving a natural number of votes. If the total number of votes is the sum of the votes received by each candidate, and each candidate received less than 1% of the total votes, what is the minimum possible total number of votes? The answer is 134.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..27}. f n \<le> N * n div 100"
and h1 : "sum f {1..27} = N"
shows  "N \<ge> 134"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134
 ### Proof
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
 We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.
 Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.
 The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.

 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and N :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..27}. f n \<le> N * n div 100"
and h1 : "sum f {1..27} = N"
shows  "N \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: For a function $f$ and a natural number $N$, if for all natural numbers $n$ from 1 to 27, $f(n)$ is less than or equal to $\frac{Nn}{100}$, and the sum of $f(n)$ from $n=1$ to $n=27$ equals $N$, what is the minimum value for $N$? The final answer is 134.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes votes :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and total_votes :: int
assumes h0 : "total_votes > 0"
and h1 : "sum votes {1..27} = total_votes"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..27}. votes i * 100 < total_votes * (votes i + 1)"
shows  "total_votes \<ge> 134"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134
 ### Proof
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
 We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.
 Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.
 The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.

 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes votes :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and total_votes :: int
assumes h0 : "total_votes > 0"
and h1 : "sum votes {1..27} = total_votes"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1..27}. votes i * 100 < total_votes * (votes i + 1)"
shows  "total_votes \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In an election, there are 27 candidates and a total number of votes that is greater than zero. If the sum of the votes for each candidate equals the total number of votes, and for every candidate, the number of their votes times 100 is less than the total number of votes times (the number of their votes plus one), find the minimum possible value for the total number of votes. The final answer is 134.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes committee_size :: nat and votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 27 \<longrightarrow> votes i \<le> committee_size"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 27 \<longrightarrow> (votes i / committee_size) * 100 < votes i"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134
 ### Proof
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
 We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.
 Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.
 The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.
 $\centerline{{\bf OR}}$
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes committee_size :: nat and votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 27 \<longrightarrow> votes i \<le> committee_size"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<le> 27 \<longrightarrow> (votes i / committee_size) * 100 < votes i"
shows  "committee_size \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: The size of a committee is such that for each of its 27 members, their votes do not exceed the total size of the committee. Furthermore, for every member, the percentage of their votes relative to the total committee size is less than the number of votes they have. What is the minimum size of the committee? The final answer is 134.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and percentage :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and members :: nat
assumes h0 : "sum votes {1..27} = members"
and h1 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..27}. percentage i = votes i / members * 100"
and h2 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..27}. percentage i < votes i"
shows  "members \<ge> 134"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134
 ### Proof
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
 We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.
 Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.
 The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.
 $\centerline{{\bf OR}}$
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes votes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and percentage :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and members :: nat
assumes h0 : "sum votes {1..27} = members"
and h1 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..27}. percentage i = votes i / members * 100"
and h2 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..27}. percentage i < votes i"
shows  "members \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a voting body of members, divided into 27 subgroups. The total number of votes is equal to the number of members, and the percentage of votes for each subgroup is given by the formula (votes of subgroup / total members) * 100. If the percentage of votes for each subgroup is less than the actual number of votes in that subgroup, what is the minimum possible number of members? The final answer is 134.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members votes :: nat
assumes h0 : "votes = members div 27"
and h1 : "\<forall> candidate. votes candidate > (votes candidate - 1) / 100 * members"
shows  "members \<ge> 134"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The members of a distinguished committee were choosing a president, and each member gave one vote to one of the 27 candidates.  For each candidate, the exact percentage of votes the candidate got was smaller by at least 1 than the number of votes for that candidate. What is the smallest possible number of members of the committee? The final Answer is 134
 ### Proof
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, $n_k$ be the number of votes for candidate $k$, and let $p_k$ be the percentage of votes for candidate $k$ for $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$.
 We have $$n_k \ge p_k+1 = {{100n_k}\over t} +1.$$Adding these 27 inequalities yields $t \ge 127$.
 Solving for $n_k$ gives $n_k \ge \displaystyle{t \over{t-100}}$, and, since $n_k$ is an integer, we obtain $$n_k \ge \biggl\lceil{t \over{t-100}}\biggr\rceil,$$where the notation $\lceil x\rceil$ denotes the least integer that is greater than or equal to $x$.
 The last inequality is satisfied for all $k= 1,2, \dots, 27$ if and only if it is satisfied by the smallest $n_k$, say $n_1$. Since $t \ge 27n_1$, we obtain $$t \ge 27 \biggl\lceil{t \over {t-100}} \bigg\rceil \quad (1)$$and our problem reduces to finding the smallest possible integer $t\ge127$ that satisfies the inequality (1).
 If ${t \over {t-100}} > 4$, that is, $t \le 133$, then $27\left\lceil{t\over {t-100}}\right\rceil \ge27 \cdot5=135$ so that the inequality (1) is not satisfied.
 Thus $\boxed{134}$ is the least possible number of members in the committee. Note that when $t=134$, an election in which 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each satisfies the conditions of the problem.
 $\centerline{{\bf OR}}$
 Let $t$ be the number of members of the committee, and let $m$ be the least number of votes that any candidate received. It is clear that $m \ne 0$ and $m \ne 1$. If $m=2$, then $2 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{2}{t}$, so $t \ge 200$.
 Similarly, if $m=3$, then $3 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{3}{t}$, and $t \ge 150$; and if $m=4$, then $4 \ge 1+100 \cdot \frac{4}{t}$, so $t \ge 134$.
 When $m \ge 5$, $t \ge 27 \cdot 5=135$.
 Thus $t \ge 134$. Verify that $t$ can be $\boxed{134}$ by noting that the votes may be distributed so that 1 candidate receives 30 votes and the remaining 26 candidates receive 4 votes each.
 *)

theorem
fixes members votes :: nat
assumes h0 : "votes = members div 27"
and h1 : "\<forall> candidate. votes candidate > (votes candidate - 1) / 100 * members"
shows  "members \<ge> 134"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Assume that in a group, each member casts a vote. The number of votes a candidate gets is one twenty-seventh of the total number of members. If each candidate receives more votes than one percent less of the total number of members, what is the minimum number of members in the group? The final answer is 134.
